Body:
I can't tell you anything about French; sorry.

I can tell you, however, that English does have a present tense but does not have a future tense. Instead, English speakers refer to future time in any number of ways:

  • Bill will leave tomorrow. (will is a Modal, and all modals can refer to the future); e.g,
  • Bill may leave tomorrow.
  • Bill might leave tomorrow.
  • Bill could leave tomorrow.
  • Bill can leave tomorrow.
  • Bill would leave tomorrow.
  • Bill shouldleave tomorrow.
  • Bill must leave tomorrow.

Then there are lots of other constructions that can refer to the future; many are modal paraphrases:

  • Bill is going to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill is to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill has to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill wants to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill is ought to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill needs to leave tomorrow.
  • Bill needed to leave tomorrow. (past tense, but the leaving is future)

Etc.

Really, English is much simpler if you merely ignore the term "Future Tense"; it just confuses people.
